subtitle: We have now released issue 3 of the New Thinking Allowed magazine.
Download it for free at newthinkingallowed.org.
New Thinking Allowed is a non-profit endeavor.
Your contributions to the New Thinking Allowed
Foundation make a meaningful difference in
our ability to produce new videos.
Thinking Allowed – conversations on the leading edge of knowledge and discovery
with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome.
I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today we'll be exploring how to cultivate psychic abilities.
My guest is Sean McNamara.
He is the author of over a dozen books on numerous topics related to parapsychology.
We've already done interviews about UFOs and their impact on our culture.
We've talked about psychedelics and its relationship
to psychic abilities, but Sean has written
about out-of-body experience, about meditation,
about remote viewing, about telekinesis, and
many other aspects of psychic functioning.
He's been leading groups to train these abilities for years.
Welcome Sean.
Thanks Jeff.
It's great to be here.
It's great to be with you and once again thank you for making the trip from Denver
to Albuquerque to be with me here in this little studio.
Thanks.
So, we were talking earlier about your journey.
We've been involved in writing step-by-step
manuals for people to develop psychic abilities,
but you said something that struck me and maybe
it's a good entry point into our discussion
that you feel like you're ready to give that
phase of your life up, that training people
to cultivate psychic abilities and to continue
to cultivate your own is no longer as big
a priority as it once was.
Yeah, it's an interesting time for me because
I've taught a lot of people these abilities
in the classroom and online and through my
books and something happened in the past year
when I was doing the research with psychedelics and psychic abilities.
It was specifically when I did the LSD experiment
that I had a spiritual experience unlike anything
I've ever felt before with psychedelics and without.
So, a lot of my time has been spent meditating.
This surpassed all of it and it was a sense of satisfaction and understanding that this
ordinary life is fine.
I couldn't choose a less exciting way to describe
it, but that it's intrinsic to reality, to
the universe and I think part of my motivation
used to be to try and develop my psychic abilities
as if it would improve me as a person or
give me greater access to something or maybe
even make me more happy somehow.
And after these years practicing for myself
and teaching it to others, I've come to what
I'm sure is a well-known conclusion that no,
being more psychic doesn't bring you more
happiness necessarily.
It doesn't necessarily make you a better person.
And I think I've just done it so much too
that I can put it to bed for myself that it's
time for me to turn my attention to more ordinary
things or just regular life because now with
this understanding that I had from that experience,
the ordinary aspect of life is just as exciting
for me as the psychic world is.
I still think it's beautiful, it's exciting.
Last month I taught 20 people in the mountains
in a place called Estes Park in Colorado.
We spent a week together developing their
clairvoyance and telepathy and it was wonderful.
It was perhaps the best psychic effect I've seen produced in any group I've led.
And I can't explain why, but they worked hard, that's certainly part of it.
And it was really inspiring.
But even with that, I think I've just come to
a point where when I meditate now, it really
is just to be here in my body just as it is,
just to be with life as it is, no longer to
try and become something more or to escape
anything, which I think was always an undertone
of how I used to practice before.
I'll always consider it one of the most inspiring
and joy creating aspects of my life for these
few years when I taught people how to access
their own abilities because I saw amazing
things and the people who experience it, they've
experienced something that they've been looking
for for a long time and it was not all that difficult.
So they got it and they could use it in any way
they wanted, part of their spiritual understanding
or just psychic training or just the fun of being alive.
So I'm always going to appreciate it that way, is this beautiful memory shared with
other people.
What you're saying reminds me of the distinction
between the Vajrayana Buddhism of Tibet, which
I believe you've practiced, and Zen.
In Zen they say chopping wood and carrying water
before enlightenment or after enlightenment
is beautiful.
That's what life is about.
In Vajrayana Buddhism it's about reaching to
the tutelary deities and traveling through
the Bardo Plains and opening up your chakras
and all of these mystical experiences and
the Zen people are saying chopping wood and
carrying water is just as good as any of that.
So I think there's, in my life I experienced
this in between, working really hard and trying
to develop myself according to certain levels
that have been described in the scriptures
and things like that, ways to measure spiritual
progress, and then somewhere along the way
realizing that the top of the mountain was
already present on the first step and I don't
have to try and keep climbing, I could rest and
I'm by no means claiming any sort of enlightenment
or that I've reached some sort of spiritual peak or anything like that.
I don't make that claim, it's just that I got
what I was looking for through the psychic
exploration and through working with other
people and I probably will from time to time
still train people because connecting with people brings me joy.
So I could do that or I could teach piano
classes, I don't know, that's just an example,
but just teaching something or working with people, that still brings me joy.
So for that reason alone, I might still continue
to train, but for my own development of experience
so much, I don't know if I can do any more and I kind of just want to focus on regular
things.
Well, you're going through some sort of a
phase shift, which I think is a normal thing
that people do from time to time.
On the other hand, you've got many readers of
your books and workshops and so on, they're
probably going to demand more from you.
We'll see.
I sort of just follow the thread of my life and
something might arise that keeps me involved
somehow or maybe I'm just taking a break for
a long time, but that you bring up the books.
I wrote them in such a way that if I got hit
by a bus tomorrow, nobody would need me for
their development because all the instructions are in the books.
I took inspiration in my writing style from when I taught myself to have an out-of-body
experience, which kicked all this off for me.
I learned it from a book.
The author was William Buhlmann and I also
read books by other authors like Robert Monroe
and others, but I really like Buhlmann's style.
Through his books, he teaches in a way that he leaves it up to the individual, here are
the instructions, you do the work and you will have the experience.
No need for a special blessing or permission
or going to expensive, like very expensive
retreats.
I'm not against charging money or paying money,
but some traditions really ask for a lot.
So none of this giving your power to someone
else stuff, it's just here are the instructions.
Maybe if you follow them and train wholeheartedly,
you'll have the experience that you're looking
for.
So I took my inspiration from him writing
my instructions that way, so I'm unnecessary
at this point.
You can just read the books or do the online
courses and if they work really hard at it,
if they really have the passion, they'll probably have the experience they want.
Well, I can say two things about where you're at from my perspective.
First of all, you're following your intuition,
which is maybe the most important psychic
gift of all.
It's like, what should I do next for my life?
What deeper question can a person ask?
And also, secondly, on the other hand, all,
let me say that, almost all of the spiritual
traditions say pursuing psychic gifts is a distraction from enlightenment and can lead
as a matter of fact to a number of different
pitfalls, namely reinforcing the ego.
I would agree with that.
So for a while, I took the view that I was learning these psychic abilities as a way
of investigating reality.
So for me, it was a spiritual path.
That was just my approach.
I don't teach it that way, but people can
take it that way if they want to make it their
spiritual path.
It was a way of observing reality.
So in a way, it's a type of science, it's just parapsychology, science.
And it was in a way that was free of some
of the religious overlays and free of dogma,
even though science has its own dogmas, of course.
But so I was using it that way and I saw that it does have a limit.
It does have a limit.
And in myself and through interactions with
others, I do see that it can inflate the ego
or it can maintain the ego.
It can be an obstacle.
And really, it's however a person is, it really
just amps everything up because then they
just become more of who they are.
And there's nothing necessarily wrong with
that, that it can, you know, even in the some
of the spiritual circles that I run in, I see
this, that some people really get a little
bit aggressive or there's a little bit of I'm better than you kind of thing or in the
making claims that may not be true.
So it's really tricky.
I think training in psychic abilities has the same problems that any other spiritual
group would have or maybe that are even present
in UFO groups or in corporate America or the
church down the street.
You know, it's just a human thing.
So I think all the same obstacles are there.
That's neither good nor bad.
It's just the way things are, but I'm following
my intuition for sure to say I think I'm ready
for a break and maybe it's only temporary and maybe it'll just be a time of my life
that happened that I can always look back on fondly for the most part.
Well, let's talk about some of the details now.
Practically all of your books, to my
understanding, are step-by-step instructions.
You do this, then you do that, and maybe you
avoid doing something along the way as if
there's a process that is to be followed if you're going to unfold these abilities.
The process leads to particular identifiable results.
You follow the process and you reach the goal.
Then another point of view, and I think it's
probably one that I lean towards for, is that
psychic abilities are not going to be controlled by the ego.
They appear according to some sort of higher logic.
They come when they come and it's very, very
risky to set yourself up as a psychic counselor
or a psychic remote viewer who is, you know,
for hire because some days are good days and
some days are bad days and we haven't yet
figured out exactly why, although we can point
to all kinds of factors like, you know, the distractions that come up in normal living.
The way I teach these techniques, they're very meditative.
They're about relaxation.
They're about surrender, which has the echoes
of meditation instructions in them to actually
soften the sense of self and soften the division between self and other.
So if someone can do that, then the practice
does take on that spiritual dimension that
when someone fails to follow the instructions
and they start pushing, let's say they're
trying to do telekinesis and move a little piece of tinfoil balanced on a needle under
a glass container, they're trying to move it and instead of following the meditative
instructions, they're trying to force it and
they're, you know, nothing happens because
the tension, the psychological tension, perhaps
the energetic tension, if that's a play, the
transfer of information stops flowing because
this big sense of self really wants something
to happen and that is moving in the opposite
direction of what really seems to work better,
which is completely softening, opening, letting go and relaxing deeply.
And I think those instructions work well across
the spectrum of psychic perception, especially
with clairvoyance and telepathy.
When you're the receiver, just relax and let go and don't worry about the results.
Yeah, but when you're doing psychokinesis or telepathic transmission, often it's the
opposite, that you want to be energized and
Andrija Puharich is, as you know in his book
Beyond Telepathy, talks about the adrenergic
state, you've got your adrenaline going or
all of the research on what are known as crisis apparitions, when somebody is in an
accident or they're even dying, that's when other people get telepathic messages from
them.
Absolutely.
There's a lot of energy in being the sender.
So in telepathy, sending the message, you want to be energized.
With telekinesis, there is that quality of energy to it, that if we think of, imagine
a river flowing down a mountain in Colorado,
the flow of the water has so much energy and
power to it, yet it's effortless for the river.
It's not trying to flow, it lets go and it just is and the flow happens naturally.
So in telekinesis, when someone follows the instructions, they're really just opening
and then whatever needs to flow, flows naturally.
It's that when someone, which is the most
powerful state for the energy flow, when it's
just allowed rather than forced.
The act of forcing actually is like putting a dam in the river and stops the flow.
So if we can let go and open, then whatever
flow or transformation or sending of information
happens at the best quality.
So we did an experiment, my friends and I, years ago with remote viewing, and we used
that adrenergic principle of Puharic.
And what we did was during the feedback stage
of the experiment, when people were seeing
the target that they had been trying to perceive
several hours earlier, so at that point they
become the sender.
I had them dunk their arms in buckets of ice cold water to cause them pain.
This is a common technique in psychology because
it doesn't cause permanent damage at all.
It raises the blood pressure a little bit, it gets people excited, it's just a feeling
of pain with the idea that it would enhance the information transfer across space and
time.
In other words, they're sending a target image to themselves in the past.
That's the idea, the feedback.
So it's beautiful telepathy with oneself across time.
And that was one of the experiments when we correctly predicted the Pick 3 lottery as
a team.
So there's something to that that we can use
our physiology a certain way to perhaps boost
the psychic signal, if that's really what's happening.
I think as humans we're still trying to figure that out.
So overall there's that balance of energy and allowing, setting a direction to one's
intention, and then letting go.
So when someone practices archery, there is the initial tension of drawing the bow and
pulling the arrow back, but for the arrow to fly one must let go.
So that's the sweet quality with psychic abilities,
building up the tension, setting your intention,
and then letting go completely.
And then waiting.
There's a lot of waiting for something to
happen, that happens with spoon bending too.
Sometimes when we in a group gather and we're
screaming at the spoon after we've gathered
the energies, bend, bend, bend.
The next instruction is generally wait, let go, just let go.
And at a certain time, in a certain moment,
you'll feel the impulse of, oh, I should check.
And then the spoon gives very easily.
Sometimes when people scream bend, bend, bend,
and immediately try to bend the spoon, nothing
happens or they're using 100% muscular force because they're not letting go.
There needs to be that letting go, almost to just get out of the way so that whatever
larger force is at play, it has room to come
in and soften the metal, if that's what's
happening with spoon bending, or take away
some of the atomic structure, if that's what's
happening.
There are different hypotheses, but so it is
the balance of trying and then allowing and
letting go.
You're putting your finger on a very key point.
I know in my own life, for example, I don't call myself a psychic at all, but my life
has been guided by certain events.
There was a time in my life when I had a
dream – we talked about this earlier – I was
agonizing for months.
That was the stress.
I knew I had to change my career direction.
I was a young man at the time, 1972, and I was a graduate student in criminology.
I had had a mystical experience, very powerful.
My great-uncle Harry came to me at the moment
of his death and sort of took me along on
a journey into the afterlife.
When I came out of that dream, I was crying tears of joy.
It was so wonderful, and singing a sacred song from the Jewish tradition.
At that point I knew I could no longer continue
on the path I was on, similar to your path.
I was working in the psychiatric unit of San
Quentin Prison, doing group therapy with murderers
and rapists.
I thought the time has come to shift my whole
career direction away from the negative side
of human deviance, which is a fascinating field, to the positive.
To explore mysticism, intuition, creativity, and psychic functioning.
But there were no ways to do that.
So I agonized for months.
I think it was very important that I did spend
months thinking, how am I going to do this?
Can I do that?
Can I go this way or check the university or find out who can help me?
And there seemed to be nothing.
And then one day finally I let go.
At that moment I knew the answer was going to come to me in a dream.
I just knew.
I didn't know what the answer was, but I
knew that that night there would be a dream.
It was a certainty.
I can't say how I knew, but I knew.
And indeed, I had this dream – I've talked about it many times, I think you have heard
me talk about it – where I was visiting some friends in their home.
They weren't there.
I found a key.
I let myself in.
I found a magazine called eye, E-Y-E, eye.
I went down the floor, paged through it, and
woke up from the dream knowing that's the
answer and still not knowing what it was.
But it was an amazing, I would say, guidance
from a higher source or psychic abilities
because I acted out the dream, went to that apartment, found a magazine right where I
knew I'd find it.
And I also happened to know where they hid the
key so I could let myself in because nobody
was there.
And that was the magazine that 50 years ago
led me to what I'm doing with you today right
at this moment, having an interview.
So of course, that took months.
But again, it's the process of tightening up, focusing, stressing out if you need to
stress out, and then letting go.
It's a universal process, I think.
It's like giving birth, right?
I think, from what I know about people who
give birth, the tension, the pushing, pushing,
and finally there's the release.
Well they say sometimes, what, the boy is the father of the man.
In a way, I gave birth to myself.
And you, aside with following your intuition,
as part of that, that's really important,
you trusted yourself.
I think for a lot of people the challenge is you receive some guidance or a direction
or a dream and then, can I trust it?
Can I trust myself?
Should I do this or should I just brush it under the rug?
And you trusted it, you followed through and
the results are undeniable because of that.
It was a life-changing decision and the time I
made it, it led me to my career as an interviewer.
But when I made that decision, I didn't own a radio or a television.
And I had this hippie-like idea that all electronic communication was phony.
I'll admit, a lot of it is, but at the time I wanted nothing to do with anything.
I thought only face-to-face communication was real.
But I changed my mind then, I'm glad I did.
It's led to the life I've been living and enjoying so much for decades.
And we still get to have the face-to-face and now share it this way.
But sometimes you really need to stress out.
So balancing that, yeah, stressing out is okay, as long as at some point you either
get too tired that you have to let go or you're
smart enough to say, I've stressed out enough
and now I'm going to rest and wait to see what happens.
And there's a trust that the universe will respond in some way.
But also with regard to being psychic, now I've had lots of small psychic experiences
in my life.
I don't try to make them happen usually, although
occasionally I've been in the laboratory and
done things.
The big ones like that, I've had two or three
big experiences in my life and they've set
a pattern that in that case, for example, lasted for 50 years or more.
You don't need to be psychic all the time
when you find one that sets you on the right
course for the rest of your life.
Yeah, it's similar to psychedelics in that
way where some people only want to do it one
time and when they're done they say that's great and they never do it again because it
gave them all the information they needed
about themselves or about their beliefs about
reality and that's it.
And the rest of their life moves forward
from that and they never have to do it again.
So yeah, it can be that way, all you need is
one moment of insight and the rest of your
life goes in the direction that you want or that maybe is destined, I don't know what
language to use here, but yeah.
Ram Dass once said, once you get the message, you can hang up the phone.
Right, that's perfect, that's perfect and I think maybe that's why I'm starting to
back away from my involvement with psychic exploration because I think I can hang up
the phone.
Well, and there's a deeper question that
people need to ask themselves, which is why?
Why do they want to do this?
What's their goal?
Such an important question.
I even asked myself once and all, what do I really want and I still am unable to answer
that question completely, which is troubling to me.
I think it's been a cause of a lot of problems
for myself in my life that I've never had
a crystal clear vision for where I want to
go or what I want to do or who I want to be.
And maybe that's okay, but I can see how it could be very helpful.
There are people out there who have become
enormously successful and happy because they
knew they had a vision and they stuck with it
and followed that thread all the way there.
They just, somehow they were born knowing this is what I want to be when I grow up.
My old friend Gary Zukoff, the author of The
Seat of the Soul and many other books, I once
called him and on his answering machine I got his message.
He says, please leave a message.
Tell me who you are and what you want and
if you can do that, you're well ahead of 90%
of the people.
Hahahahahahahaha, yeah, so true.
Maybe I thought practicing psychic abilities
would help me find out the answer to that
question, but they haven't.
Well, it's a philosophical question, but even deeper than that it has a spiritual
import as well.
I'm reminded of when I took a psychic training
program with my friend Ted Owens, the PK man.
This is a guy who was the master of psychokinesis.
He would point his finger and lightning would
strike and control hurricanes, tornadoes,
UFO appearances, earthquakes, major power blackouts.
So I took his training course because for a long time I didn't believe I should pay
attention to him because like everybody he
had misses and his personality could be very
abrasive at times and dangerous.
But I came to a point where I said, I've got to pay attention to this man.
I'll take his training program.
I did with some friends and at the beginning
of the program he said, well, what do you
want to do with this ability?
And I thought to myself, I don't want to do what you do.
I'm not interested in power blackouts and
making lightning strike or UFO, calling down
UFOs, I said.
And I thought about it.
And I said, what I really want in my life is
to be a communicator to the world at large
about the realities of psychic functioning.
So I think the training program I think was effective.
It was only a few months after I completed that
program that I launched my first television
series that was successful beyond my wildest dreams, actually.
And did you find that all the pieces fell into place and you could see them falling
into place or was some of it an act of faith
of just moving forward one day at a time and
I've been fortunate.
Now, I don't seek people who are psychics, but I have a lot of friends who are.
And on one occasion, one of my friends, Carol
Dryer, who has been a guest on the original
Thinking Allowed series, a very well-known psychic to the stars in Los Angeles and a
lovely woman, she had a little cable TV show
in Los Angeles and she invited me down to
at her expense to be a guest, interview on her program.
So we did that.
And then she said to me, the reason that she
did all this, she said, I want you to go back
to San Francisco where you lived at the time.
She says, you do exactly what I've done.
You put this little cable TV program together,
she said, and I promise you it will be successful
beyond your wildest dreams. Wow!
And so from time to time, I've had psychic friends who felt the urge to reach out to
me in ways like that and I would say I was
open to that and, you know, when psychic things
come along, I'm open to them, but I'm not seeking them.
And that's maybe the most trustworthy type of psychic information to receive when you
don't start off asking for it, that it just comes.
Like in remote viewing, you can't be your own tasker and the viewer because then your
conscious mind will get in the way and create
probably a false impression of the psychic
information.
It has to be completely blind in a remote viewing experiment for the best results.
So in your case, you're having a series of blind
experiments where you're not even requesting
but information is coming unexpectedly and then you trust it.
Yeah.
Now, I'll admit there are occasions when people
who thought they had psychic abilities reached
out to me and I could tell right away it was bogus.
I had a fellow who thought of himself as a
psychic healer, this is, oh my gosh, 40 years
ago came to me and said, I need to tell you, you've got syphilis.
I'm so glad I ignored him.
That's tough.
In this realm there is a lot of unrequested advice.
Yeah.
I mean, normally I don't encourage people to give unsolicited advice.
Usually it's not a good thing to do but occasionally
when it comes to me from certain people who
I know are gifted and they have a certain aura about them that I can trust and it's
turned out to be incredibly valuable.
And I wonder if the information about you came to them spontaneously.
It's not like they were setting out to get your attention on purpose.
No, I don't think so.
No.
Whereas this other character, maybe he just
wanted your attention or something like that.
Something like that.
So it takes the art of discernment to distinguish
between an authentic, mystical, psychic impulse
coming from someone or whether it's coming
from a deep psychological need or an ego need.
Yeah, the water gets muddy sometimes for sure.
That's why when I teach, I like giving the students exercises that are evidence-based.
They'll never be fooling themselves or making something up.
You'll see the results.
Either you had a hit or a miss and let's work
on the quality if it wasn't entirely a great
hit.
But you got some aspects, what can we do to refine it?
So it's important that we don't fool ourselves
in this realm because it's very easy to do.
It's a natural thing to want to be special or
want to exhibit special powers or abilities.
There's nothing wrong with that, but then we
have to see for sure instead of just trying
to convince the world of that evidence.
But the evidence is important because in my classes from time to time, let's say energy
healers will come and they'll come to get that kind of direct evidence because they
want to make sure that when a patient or a
client of theirs is on the table and they're
holding their hands over them healing, that something is actually happening.
So when they come to a telekinesis class and they
actually can move the object from a distance,
it's okay, thank you, that's verification.
Or if someone practices telepathy and their impressions match the image that the sender
was sending, if they happen to be a psychic reader, they can be sure that, okay, I do
have this ability.
I'm not just making it up.
It's one of the basic learning paradigms is feedback.
That makes me think of Charles Tart, one of his
books, Learning to Use Extrasensory Perception.
He explains how giving someone immediate
feedback is a really powerful form of learning.
That that reinforces the ability instead of giving someone feedback delayed, maybe the
next day or sometime far off in the future.
Immediate feedback really helps someone develop their ability in a good way.
So that book was important for him.
He wrote that book, if I remember rightly, in the late 1960s or maybe even early 70s.
It was largely a reaction to card guessing
experiments where people didn't get the immediate
feedback card after card.
Maybe they got some feedback after they went through a deck of 25 cards.
They reported what they called the decline effect.
The scores dropped.
They started out high and then they declined.
Tart said, well, that's what you'd expect when you don't get immediate feedback.
Right.
He really has his finger on the human quality
of psychic experimentation, the human aspect,
the emotional aspect, the psychological drive.
It's just like when you train an athlete, the coach has to know the athlete's moods,
their diet, how weather affects them, what's
going on with their family at the time.
All of these factors come into play with how
well an athlete learns and performs and improves
or heals from injury.
It's the same thing with psychic development.
Dr. Tart figured that out, that giving someone
very fast feedback helps the psychic develop
themselves versus making them do these long,
boring tests, all these trials before they
actually find out if they were right or wrong.
Of course, there would be a decline effect.
He knew that and a lot of people don't and
they put these people through these mindless
tests.
It's really important to keep things interesting.
So when I did this recent retreat, we had a week together.
I don't think we ever repeated the same experiment at all.
So every hour or two, it was a completely
different exercise, whether it was clairvoyance
or telepathy, but switching it up over and
over again, taking breaks and keeping people
focused through fun and relaxation and social connection.
So all of these are important.
The social aspect is so important for the performance aspect.
Novelty is important, that the test doesn't become boring over time.
Which is difficult for scientists because boring, repetitive tests are very easy to
score and measure.
And then you can do your statistical analysis
and all these things that people like to do
when they're trying to prove something or
